answers.text: nations with overwhelming power and influence in the rest of the world

qas.question: Who first used the term superpower?
Who were the three original superpowers?

answers.text: British Empire, the United States, and the Soviet Union

qas.question: Who lost their superpower status in 1950s?

answers.text: those nations which exercise a degree of global influence, but are insufficient to be decisive on international affairs

qas.question: Who first used the term overwhelming influence?

plausible_answers.text: the British Empire, the United States, and the Soviet Union

qas.question: What are the regional powers according to William T. R. Fox?
When did the Soviet Union lose its superpower status?
How many original middle powers are there?
Which nations have a degree of overwhelming power but are not decisive internationally?

context: Since the end of the World Wars, the term "great power" has been joined by a number of other power classifications. Foremost among these is the concept of the superpower, used to describe those <a0_0>nations with overwhelming power and influence in the rest of the world<a0_0/>. It was first coined in 1944 by <a1_0><b5_0>William T.R. Fox<b5_0/><a1_0/> and according to him, there were <b8_0>three<b8_0/> superpowers: <b6_0>the <a2_0>British Empire, the United States, and the Soviet Union<b6_0/><a2_0/>. But by <b7_0>the mid-1950s<b7_0/> the <a3_0>British Empire<a3_0/> lost its superpower status, leaving the United States and the Soviet Union as the world's superpowers.[nb 2] The term <b9_0>middle power<b9_0/> has emerged for <a4_0>those nations which exercise a degree of global influence, but are insufficient to be decisive on international affairs<a4_0/>. Regional powers are those whose influence is generally confined to their region of the world.
